block.p: * Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, will withdraw from personal insurance in Oklahoma, Washington and Arkansas because of financial losses and too little business. * Air New Zealand, Wellington, and Qantas Airways, Australia, will join forces on their Pacific routes in April. * CML Group Inc., Acton, Mass., a retailer, said the Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs had sold all of his 930,000 CML shares to Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Shearson has sold the shares to retail and institutional customers. No terms were disclosed. * Crum & Forster Inc., Basking Ridge, N.J., an insurance holding company, said its Navco Corp. unit had been sold to Motors Insurance Corp., a subsidiary of General Motors Acceptance Corp. The price was about $250 million. * Endiama, the Angolan state diamond company, and De Beers Centenary A.G., London, signed a pact that allows the country to re-enter the De Beers group after five years. * Federated Department Stores Inc., Cincinnati, and Allied Stores Corp., New York, will be allowed to borrow $100 million to buy merchandise from foreign suppliers in 1991 and 1992, a Federal bankruptcy judge has ruled. * General Motors Corp., Detroit, will begin buying back class H common stock from G.M. officials who received them as compensation. * Hershey Foods Corp., Hershey, Pa., will buy American Italian Pasta Co., Excelsior Springs, Mo., an operator of a pasta manufacturing plant, for undisclosed terms. * Publicker Industries, Old Greenwich, Conn., a producer of carbon dioxide and related products, said it had acquired 9 of 10 companies it had agreed to buy from Hanson Industries, a unit of Hanson P.L.C., a consumer products company. The purchase price was $31.7 million. * Sprague Technologies Inc., Stamford, Conn., a maker of electronic components, has sold its semiconductor group to Sanken Electric Co. for $58 million. * Walgreen Co., Deerfield, Ill., a drugstore operator, said a Phoenix bankruptcy court had awarded it the assets of Medicare-Glaser drugstores in St. Louis, including four stores. The company will transfer the inventory, prescription files and photofinishing business of 67 other Medicare-Glaser stores to Walgreen outlets. The transaction is valued at $12.2 million.

* Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, will withdraw from personal insurance in Oklahoma, Washington and Arkansas because of financial losses and too little business. * Air New Zealand, Wellington, and Qantas Airways, Australia, will join forces on their Pacific routes in April. * CML Group Inc., Acton, Mass., a retailer, said the Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs had sold all of his 930,000 CML shares to Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc. Shearson has sold the shares to retail and institutional customers. No terms were disclosed. * Crum & Forster Inc., Basking Ridge, N.J., an insurance holding company, said its Navco Corp. unit had been sold to Motors Insurance Corp., a subsidiary of General Motors Acceptance Corp. The price was about $250 million. * Endiama, the Angolan state diamond company, and De Beers Centenary A.G., London, signed a pact that allows the country to re-enter the De Beers group after five years. * Federated Department Stores Inc., Cincinnati, and Allied Stores Corp., New York, will be allowed to borrow $100 million to buy merchandise from foreign suppliers in 1991 and 1992, a Federal bankruptcy judge has ruled. * General Motors Corp., Detroit, will begin buying back class H common stock from G.M. officials who received them as compensation. * Hershey Foods Corp., Hershey, Pa., will buy American Italian Pasta Co., Excelsior Springs, Mo., an operator of a pasta manufacturing plant, for undisclosed terms. * Publicker Industries, Old Greenwich, Conn., a producer of carbon dioxide and related products, said it had acquired 9 of 10 companies it had agreed to buy from Hanson Industries, a unit of Hanson P.L.C., a consumer products company. The purchase price was $31.7 million. * Sprague Technologies Inc., Stamford, Conn., a maker of electronic components, has sold its semiconductor group to Sanken Electric Co. for $58 million. * Walgreen Co., Deerfield, Ill., a drugstore operator, said a Phoenix bankruptcy court had awarded it the assets of Medicare-Glaser drugstores in St. Louis, including four stores. The company will transfer the inventory, prescription files and photofinishing business of 67 other Medicare-Glaser stores to Walgreen outlets. The transaction is valued at $12.2 million.
